Award.AwardTitle: CRM 2015 Thematic Semester: AdS/CFT, Holography, Integrability
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation by US-based researchers in two workshops that are parts of a Thematic Semester on the Anti-de-Sitter/Conformal Field Theory (AdS/CFT) correspondence. The Thematic Semester will be held at the Centre de Recherches Mathématiques (CRM) in Montreal, Canada. The term "AdS/CFT correspondence" refers to a remarkable connection between two major directions in modern theoretical physics, string theory and Yang-Mills theory. The study of this correspondence is intimately related to some of the most fundamental questions in contemporary theoretical physics, such as the formation of black holes and early-universe cosmology. The topic also has applications to quantum chromodynamics and condensed matter physics. The objective of this project is to support the participation of junior US researchers in two workshops organized within this thematic semester: "Positive Grassmannians: Applications to integrable systems and super Yang-Mills scattering amplitudes," held July 27 - 31, 2015, and "Module spaces, integrable systems, and topological recursion," held January 9 - 13, 2016.

The planned semester at the Centre de Recherches Mathématiques will represent the state of the art in the studies of the Anti-de-Sitter/Conformal Field Theory (AdS/CFT) correspondence. A special focus will be those aspects of the AdS/CFT correspondence that allow for exact solutions, such as the appearance of integrability in the planar limit of super-Yang-Mills theory, lower dimensional models, higher-spin theories, as well as topological field and topological string theories. The semester will be a unique forum that brings researchers with expertise in the AdS/CFT correspondence together with experts in integrability. This interdisciplinary activity will involve participation of many distinguished mathematicians, physicists, and mathematical physicists. The semester will provide training in these very important domains for a significant number of junior US researchers (postdocs, junior faculty, and graduate students) who participate.

More detailed description of the workshops supported by this award can be found in the webpages:
http://www.crm.umontreal.ca/2015/Amplitudes15/index_e.php http://www.crm.umontreal.ca/2016/Moduli16/index_e.php
The description of the entire thematic semester is presented in the webpage: http://www.crm.umontreal.ca/Holography2015/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to support the participation of
the young American mathematicians (junior faculty, postdoctoral fellows
and graduate students)   in the Thematic Semester  at the Center de Recherches Mathématiques (CRM)
on  the integrable systems and the  Anti-de-Sitter/Conformal Field Theory (AdS/CFT)
correspondence. The semester took place during the period July - December 2015.

The AdS/CFT correspondence  establishes a link between two major areas
of research in modern theoretical physics which are the  theory of quantum gravity  and the
conformal field theory. The AdS/CFT correspondence is intimately related  to some of the
most fundamental questions in  contemporary physics and mathematics, such as black holes
and early universe cosmology and the  elevation of quantum Yang-Mills theory to a mathematically
rigorous framework. The latter is, in essence, one of the  seven ``millennium problems'' suggested
in the turn of this century by The Clay Mathematics Institute of Cambridge.

The semester was organized as an  interdisciplinary activity with  participation of many
distinguished mathematicians, physicists and mathematical physicists. One of the key goals of
the program was to create the  opportunities for younger scientists to learn modern mathematical physics
and discuss their own projects with established experts. The specific goal of the support provided
by the NSF grant was to enable participation of young American researchers at two of the eight workshops
organized in conjunction with the semester. 

The first workshop took place during  the period  July 27 - 31, 2015, and the second  - during
the period January 9- 13, 2016. The primary focus of the  both workshops  was on some of the
mathematical features of the AdS/CFT correspondence; specifically, on its   topological, combinatorial
and algebra-geometric aspects with the strong emphasis on the role of the theory of integrable systems.

The NSF grant enabled 12 young researchers from the US  to participate in the first workshop
and 11 young  researchers from the US to participate in the second workshop.

The lecture sessions represented the main workshop's activities. All the invited speakers have
made  major contributions to the development of the topics of the workshops. 
Among them are the pioneers of the field: R. Dijkgraaf, B. Dubrovin, B. Eynard, A. Okounkov,  N. Orantin.
Also, all the speakers are known to be excellent presenters. Indeed, the workshops  provided a perfect
environment in which young researches  have learned and have been encouraged  to contribute to the new
developments in the cutting edge areas of mathematical physics represented by the workshop's topics.


The scope of presentations ranged from analyzing a particular illustrative ex-
ample to reporting on a progress in a long-term research program to provid-
ing a broad overview of future directions of research. In fact, the workshops itself
contributed greatly to understanding several new features related to the
AdS/CFT correspondence. Several new conjectures and concrete open questions
have been formulated.

Overall, the both workshops were veritable hotbeds of ideas and discussions,
with lively scientific discussion not only during the talks but also between them and afterwards.

A PRINCIPAL OUTCOME  of the NSF support was a facilitation of  the first class  training in
the new and very important domains  of mathematical physics of a significant number of junior US
researchers. Their participation in the program, the opportunity to interact with the top
people in their field, to learn from them and to expose themselves on a such high level scholarly  forum
was extremely beneficial  for the young scientists's own research and for their future careers.
